section.title: Introduction
section.paragraph: In a normal scenario, you would use a MeshInstance3D node to display a 3D mesh like a human model for the main character, but in some cases, you would like to create multiple instances of the same mesh in a scene. You could duplicate the same node multiple times and adjust the transforms manually. This may be a tedious process and the result may look mechanical. Also, this method is not conducive to rapid iterations. MultiMeshInstance3D is one of the possible solutions to this problem.

MultiMeshInstance3D, as the name suggests, creates multiple copies of a MeshInstance over a surface of a specific mesh. An example would be having a tree mesh populate a landscape mesh with trees of random scales and orientations.

section.title: Setting up the nodes
section.paragraph: The basic setup requires three nodes: the MultiMeshInstance3D node and two MeshInstance3D nodes.
One node is used as the target, the surface mesh that you want to place multiple meshes on. In the tree example, this would be the landscape.
The other node is used as the source, the mesh that you want to have duplicated. In the tree case, this would be the tree itself.
In our example, we would use a Node3D node as the root node of the scene. Your scene tree would look like this:

note.paragraph: For simplicity's sake, this tutorial uses built-in primitives.

section.paragraph: Now you have everything ready. Select the MultiMeshInstance3D node and look at the toolbar, you should see an extra button called MultiMesh next to View. Click it and select Populate surface in the dropdown menu. A new window titled Populate MultiMesh will pop up.

section.title: MultiMesh settings
section.paragraph: Below are descriptions of the options.

section.title: Target Surface
section.paragraph: The mesh used as the target surface on which to place copies of your source mesh.

section.title: Source Mesh
section.paragraph: The mesh you want duplicated on the target surface.

section.title: Mesh Up Axis
section.paragraph: The axis used as the up axis of the source mesh.

section.title: Random Rotation
section.paragraph: Randomizing the rotation around the up axis of the source mesh.

section.title: Random Tilt
section.paragraph: Randomizing the overall rotation of the source mesh.

section.title: Random Scale
section.paragraph: Randomizing the scale of the source mesh.

section.title: Scale
section.paragraph: The scale of the source mesh that will be placed over the target surface.

section.title: Amount
section.paragraph: The amount of mesh instances placed over the target surface.

Select the target surface. In the tree case, this should be the landscape node. The source mesh should be the tree node. Adjust the other parameters according to your preference. Press Populate and multiple copies of the source mesh will be placed over the target mesh. If you are satisfied with the result, you can delete the mesh instance used as the source mesh.
